message_1: A sample of radioactive materials has an initial mass of 500 grams and a half-life of 50 years. Write an equation to represent the decay of the material, and determine how much of the material remains after 100 years.
message_2:
To represent the decay of the radioactive material, we can use the exponential decay formula:

M(t) = M₀ * (1/2)^(t/T)

where:
- M(t) is the mass of the material remaining after time t
- M₀ is the initial mass of the material (500 grams in this case)
- t is the time elapsed (in years)
- T is the half-life of the material (50 years in this case)

So the equation representing the decay of the material is:

M(t) = 500 * (1/2)^(t/50)

Now, we want to find the mass of the material remaining after 100 years. We can plug t = 100 into the equation:

M(100) = 500 * (1/2)^(100/50)

M(100) = 500 * (1/2)^2

M(100) = 500 * (1/4)

M(100) = 125 grams

After 100 years, 125 grams of the radioactive material remains.
